page.title: 01The River Hamble
page.content:
The River Hamble has been of Nautical significance for many years.It was first recorded in 720A.D by a monk,St. Willibald who set out from the River Hamble for the Middle East.
About the same time this comment was made about the river's double high water, by the Venerable Bede in his Ecclesiatical histroy "... the tides meet and oppose one another beyond the mouth of the River Homelea(Hamble) which runs into that narrow sea from the land of Jutes....." Even then these tides were considered noteworthy. In 1740 Moody Janverin a master boat shipwright built Hamble House , and built a number of ships for the Royal Navy,including the the 'Lively which
